text: one week on since typhoon Haiyan hit the
Philippines and the full extent of the
devastation is still unclear from the
air the city of Tacloban still lies in
ruins and on the ground people are now
living in the open salvaging what they
can and among the ruins they're still
waiting for help here maybe a thousand
lined up in hope of food aid among them
we met Abigail widowed by the typhoon
now she and her two toddlers have been
surviving on biscuits
we will wait because there
it's a scene of confusion and
hopelessness so this is the front of the
line but as you can see there's no food
distribution going on here and some of
these people have been waiting for hours
in the Blazing Sun take a look around
and a lot of them are kids with their
families yet just feet away to lorries
laden with food but no one coordinating
distribution so the people who stay
hungry each morning now local
authorities and relief groups share
updates the Philippine government has
been criticized for a slow response but
the minister in charge told me they're
overwhelmed trucks I only have eight
trucks that are from the Armed Forces
that are delivering goods and foodstuffs
to the communities for the whole system
a charge for the whole province but it's
starting to happen now at least you can
see tackler bands main roads are clear
aid can start getting out but any
thought of rebuilding is still a long
way off
Rajesh merchandani BBC News Taliban in
the Philippines
